intro: Bupleurum kurdicum f. pseudogerardii, commonly known as the Kurdish Bupleurum, is a rare subspecies native to the mountainous regions of the Middle East. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, characterized by its distinctive umbellate inflorescences and aromatic foliage. The plant typically grows in rocky and dry habitats, showing adaptability to harsh environmental conditions. Its leaves are pinnately compound, and its flowers are usually pale yellow to white, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a valuable subject for botanical research and conservation efforts.
